stem: The nurse in a family practice clinic is reviewing the records for four adult clients. Based on the documented history and risk factors, match each client to the most appropriate priority screening intervention.

tabs.title: Nurses' Notes
tabs.content:
Patient A: Ms. Lee (25y/o female) reports her first sexual partner was at age 16. She has never had a pelvic exam. 
Patient B: Mr. Smith (52y/o male) has a 35-pack-year smoking history. He presents for a yearly wellness exam. 
Patient C: Ms. Garcia (42y/o female) states her sister was diagnosed with breast cancer at age 45. 
Patient D: Mr. Jones (47y/o male) reports no symptoms but is concerned about colorectal cancer because he 'hit the age' for screening.

tabs.content: All clients are hemodynamically stable. Mr. Smith's BP is 138/88, and he exhibits mild wheezing.

rows.text: Annual Low-Dose CT (LDCT) for Lung Cancer

rationale.correct: Pap tests start at 21 regardless of sexual activity (r2/c1). Annual LDCT (r1/c2) is for adults aged 50â€“80 who have a 20-pack-year smoking history and currently smoke or quit within 15 years. Colonoscopy (r3/c4) now starts at age 45 for everyone. Mammography (r4/c3) is prioritized for women over 40-50, especially with first-degree family history.
clinicalPearls: Lung cancer screening age was recently lowered to 50 (from 55).
Colonoscopy age was recently lowered to 45 (from 50).
Always screen for HPV and Cervical cancer starting at 21, even if the patient is 'not sexually active' according to their report.

questionTrap.trap: Coding Mr. Jones as not needing a colonoscopy because he is 'under 50'.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Remember the new USPSTF guidelines: 45 is the new 50 for colon health.
